intro: Salvia jordanii, commonly known as Jordan's sage, is a perennial herb native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its upright growth habit, hairy stems, and narrow, gray-green leaves. The plant produces striking violet to purple flowers in whorls along the stems, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It is adapted to thrive in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a drought-tolerant species. Botanically, it belongs to the Lamiaceae family, known for its aromatic properties and showy flowers.
